number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												I love this game ...That said There are 2 fundamental design flaws with it:1. the graphics are horrible ... really really bad ... not not that bad worse far worse ... think 1980's low budget game then wind back your expectations. Good games (imo) arnt all about the graphics but they're bad enough to make it hard to play.2. starting a game you are presented with a dizzying array of nations, gods and possible setups, the most complex part of the game is deciding on your setup - but you really have to understand the game quite well in order to do this, these choices are fundamental and important. There is no guidance in game that helps a new player, the 397 page pdf manual is little or no help (once you find it) googling 'dom4 nation setup' gives lots of forum postings by those who use so many acronyms they're illegible.[e.g. EA Neif Monolith E9A1E6 D6 O3P3C3G1M3D0 - really didnt help me - though now I know the game better I can see is a helpful build suggestion]In short you really have to put work in to get to the point where the game is anything more than a turn based terrirtory domino fall game of conquest.Dominions 4 is however far more than that. Yes you can just pump troops out and spread your gods dominion by attacking and taking over all other gods territories but there is so much more here once you look. Research of spells & items to forge add a lot but other than being a wider available choice you get similar tech tree approaches in many other games. Adding the divine to the game is a somewhat new, interesting and brilliant twist - the aim is not global military dominion but instead for your god to spread his dominion to the world, to spread belief in your god to the exclusion of all other gods. Belief can cross borders stepping right over a turtled mass of troops in a pinch point.As a suggestion:1. find the online pdf manual (linked in guides) play the 9 turn by rote guide to controls (found somewhere about 90 pages in interspersed with irrelevant and unhelpful history of how the game was made and waffle about the designers inspiration for the game.2. Play a Late Age (LA) Nation called Man, dont worry about nation / god setup on a small map against any random land based nation, dont research anything / forge any items just work with longbowmen to get the feel of the game.3. Play an Early Age (EA) Nation called Metlican. Google some setups but the one that works for me is :Demilich (Imprisoned): Water 4 Death 9 Nature 9, Dominion 8 Order 3 Sloth 3 Heat 2 Growth 2 Misfortune 2 Drain 2Set a commander to the spells Blessing / Divine Blessing and work with Jaguar Warriors.Use these to learn the game to the point where you feel comfortable experimenting & understand the forum post acronyms you'll find from google.I hope you enjoy the game as much as I have!

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												I like pretty graphics. I really do. But despite the somewhat unpretty graphics of the Illwinter games, I think I've sunk more hours into Dominions II than the entire Total War series combined, and Dominions III and IV have only increased my adoration. The Dominions series (and it's sister series Conquest of Elysium) is not for everyone of course. No game is for everyone. But there are free playable demo versions of the titles available, if Steam doesn't provide them just Google it, and if the idea of a TBS game with low-tech but high-depth and high-customization is appealing, then at the very least give these games a shot. If you're anything like me, this title will consume every second of your leisure time for weeks on end, and you'll be glad of it. Also, you can run it on a laptop from the mid-90''s if you have to, and that's more than you can say for a lot of other modern TBS titles. Being a god is fun, give it a try.

												Tired of strategy games that boil down to Gun vs Bigger Gun?Tired of strategies that boil down to 'I'm gonna get SUCH a big number'?\Tired of games where there are hundreds of units, but only three of them are meaningful?Try this game. content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												With nearly infinite variations, a plethora of factions with access to dozens of gods (ranging from dragons to stone pillars, all equally viable) Dominions 4 is an intimidating game to play. My first few hours were spent largely in confusion as I grappled with the sheer number of choices I could make and trying to understand the stats and rules of the units (almost all of which come with a decent back story, making the game exceptionally immersive). I've spent an unhealthy number of hours playing Sid Meiers Civilization series and while it offers superior graphics and accessibility than Dominions, Thrones of Ascension far surpasses Civilization in terms of player immersion and creativity. The vast array of chracters and nations to play is a canvas for the imaginiation, and whether I'm a stationary God-tree or Archmage, leading legions of skeletal soldiers or reptilian wizards, its always a fun time. At least once you leard just what the hell is going on.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												I discovered Dominions when it was Dom2.  That game was very hard to understand and play.  Dom3 was much, much better and Dom4 (in my opinion) is a modest improvement.  There is a lot to like about this game: building your god (I really like that part), discovering and using magic, and researching some of the over 800 spells.  Not to mention several dozen different nations to play with and each of those in THREE ages (i.e. different ages of the world).  I don't think it's possible to play the same game twice the same way; there's just too much diversity.It's easy to take this game as a series of battles: win every battle, beat the other god(s) and you win the game.  Wrong!  It is about magic and if you don't utilize magic, you will lose.  That alone makes it a challenging game to understand and play, and win.  I really like that part of the game.But here's the problem for me:  It is a massively detailed micro-manager game.  You have to check every thing in every  province, every turn, and usually every army (or part of an army) every turn, and anything and everything else in every part of the game and almost every part of the map -- every turn!  If you really, really like that in a game, this is one you must buy.  It is fun, and interesting, and deep and complex...but after a while I find it overwhelmingly tedious.

I by no means have logged many hours, but i think i've logged enough to post this to people who are wondering what going into the series as someone whos never even heard of it before buying it thinks.My interests align with strategic games. i like EU IV, hearts of iron 3 etc, i used to enjoy the total war games (not so much anymore). i liked gratuitous space battles which funnily enough does have some parralels with how the battles in this game plays out. Its deep, rewarding and difficult. Diffuclty appeals to me greatly as i find nothing more dull than just instant winning so thats another plus for me. I still haven't figured out the optimum strategy of anything by any means but its an ongoing learning process.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												10/10 - My go to for procrastination.The game is simple enough to play through the first time and crush the AI on easy using some surface elements.  After the first playthrough, you'll start playing with research, exploration, crafting, buildings, and deeper 'god customization.'The races give you plenty of options for playthrough, and the automated battles let you judge your strategy by watching a replay (which you can speed up) after each encounter.  You can make/download custom factions, change victory conditions to quite a few options.  There's a map editor and the randomn map generator is pretty fantastic as well.I like pretty much everything about this game, I wish you could be a little more detailed in the scripts after mastering some basic tactics, and that you didn't have to ration magic gems as much, but other than those small complaints, I'm a happy customer.After seeing the progress from Elysium 3 to Dominions 4, I'm seriously hoping this company comes out with another game like this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												Great game if you love strategy games. Very deep with lots of replayability!More hours into this game than any other game at least since steam has been tracking it. I also played on desura for at least a hundred hours. I think a good measure of a strategy game is how many hours you see logged for peoples reviews on here. You are a god! You can make you're own god and pick from many different styles of nations, and fight against other gods,It takes a while to figure out how everything works, since the game is so deep. You can keep upping the difficulty in many ways as you learn how to take advantage of everything you can do. With low difficulty you can have fun before you know all the ins and outs, I would recommend looking at some of the user guides. I haven't really checked out the multiplayer as it seems like it takes a long time, and my play time is sporadic and hard for me to plan.Custom map editor and generator. There are a lot of user made maps to download, and you can generate and modify your own. Also a lot of user created empires, but there is so much already in the game I haven't even downloaded any of it!You can outfit special or summoned units, or thugs as they're refered to. Sea Troll King, many types of demons, liches, giants. It adds an RPG element to the game.One of my favorite games ever!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												I discovered Dominions when it was Dom2.  That game was very hard to understand and play.  Dom3 was much, much better and Dom4 (in my opinion) is a modest improvement.  There is a lot to like about this game: building your god (I really like that part), discovering and using magic, and researching some of the over 800 spells.  Not to mention several dozen different nations to play with and each of those in THREE ages (i.e. different ages of the world).  I don't think it's possible to play the same game twice the same way; there's just too much diversity.It's easy to take this game as a series of battles: win every battle, beat the other god(s) and you win the game.  Wrong!  It is about magic and if you don't utilize magic, you will lose.  That alone makes it a challenging game to understand and play, and win.  I really like that part of the game.But here's the problem for me:  It is a massively detailed micro-manager game.  You have to check every thing in every  province, every turn, and usually every army (or part of an army) every turn, and anything and everything else in every part of the game and almost every part of the map -- every turn!  If you really, really like that in a game, this is one you must buy.  It is fun, and interesting, and deep and complex...but after a while I find it overwhelmingly tedious.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												No doubt, this game ranks close to Dwarf Fortress in terms of complexity.  That being said, it can be a really wild ride.  The basic premise is that the Pantokrator (the Overgod, think Aao if you know Forgotten Realms), has vanshied.  This leaves the lesser gods, demi-gods, demon lords, elemental kings, and even powerful "mortal" beings struggling to become the new Overgod.  The game focuses on recruiting armies and researching powerful magic to push back your opponents and become the only remaining God.  The mechanics can take a bit of getting used to (think along the lines of Risk, but with more depth from the various unit types and magic) but there are plenty of guids and manuals available, as well as an active fan base that is very helpful when it comes to questions.Also, all mechanics aside, you can play as frost giants led by the very physical embodiment of Winter itself against an undead Roman Empire led by a horror from the Void outside of reality.  Why the f**k wouldn't you want to try that?  Buy this game, be a Pretender God, and claim your rightful destiny.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												This is one of the best strategy game I have ever played. Dominions 4 is a fantasy 4x game, heavily focused on warfare and magic development... and a very distinctive God-building system (yes, you are the God of your civilization).In order to achieve your goal (rule over the world destroying your enemies, making of your God faith the only one remaining or claiming several magical sites) you will need more than controlling land and building your armies... You will have to take advantage of your nation strenghts and sinergies, take control of territories with strategic resources and special troops available, and craft special equipment for your commanders, as well as develop your magical level. You can also know what is wrong with your armies as you may actually see the battles you are involved in, knowing this way how your troops are performing, among them and against your enemies.This game has an incredible amount of nations, units, spells, enchantments, equipment... available, which is a guarantee of replayability. Content that is constantly increased by free patches.Though graphics and interface look a bit outdated, this is a very immersive game, with lots of possibilities, and an important community modding it and with lots of multiplayer games active. Highly recommendable.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												I find Dominions 4 to be fascinatingly intricate and polished, a credible result for 10+ years of dedicated evolution over four sequels, from what I've gathered. I've seen that in series before, yet somehow I'm still impressed here. Right after I got it, I told a friend of mine who spent about a year of his free time playing two humongous maps of Age of Wonders II--something I never expected [was a typo] when I gave it to him as his first brush with the genre--that my initial estimate puts Dominions 4 at about (AoW2)^2 in content. Personally, I relish a steep learning curve: grand strategy titles and deeply dynamic RPG character building systems have been particular pleasures down this line. Nevertheless, starting Dominions 4 I was surprised such as I haven't been in a long time to see I had underestimated how much I wouldn't know.At first I was moderately impressed at the apparent scope of the thing, and I started to get burnt out on my course of study about the time I felt I could look at the nations lists with their dozens of choices and think I could describe the basic flavor for all of them. But then for the first time I looked at my first details about the magical and crafting systems and as ideas and dimensions began to click I was truly impressed like I had finally shifted the top layer of this giant package, and underneath it was still layers more good and integrated stuff!The more I've dug up hour after hour of yet more complimentary game dynamics and worldbuilding flavor, the more I've thought I wish I had bought this game full price instead of on sale: all the more power to the developers if they're this kind of craftsmen.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
tl;dr If you really enjoy turn-based strategy games and if you don't mind a brobdingnagian learning curve, it's one of the best. If you don't like to spend hours over the handbook and browsing through the game before even starting, leave it and play something easily digestible.Short reviewI love it: More than 500 units, a big load of spells, multiple styles of the different races,First the only "bad" part of the game: The graphics are old, it looks like around 2000 and it feels like it was never updated. For me that's no problem, I don't mind bad graphics in an awesome game.And the best part: A big, huge handbook like in the old games; about 300 pages long, not really uptodate, but I really enjoy reading it and learning parts of the game I didn't know.Some might say Dom4 is such a mod re-release of Dom3 and it feels in some ways like that, but I gladly pay the few bucks to keep the game updated and mostly bug-free.Dominions 3 was my favourite strategy game. Dominions 4 is much improved, allows kind of alliances, new game goals and (I repeat myself) no more game breaking bugs. 4 friends and I spent multiple weekends playing together and against each other; I enjoyed every moment. My personal favourite game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												I love this game ...That said There are 2 fundamental design flaws with it:1. the graphics are horrible ... really really bad ... not not that bad worse far worse ... think 1980's low budget game then wind back your expectations. Good games (imo) arnt all about the graphics but they're bad enough to make it hard to play.2. starting a game you are presented with a dizzying array of nations, gods and possible setups, the most complex part of the game is deciding on your setup - but you really have to understand the game quite well in order to do this, these choices are fundamental and important. There is no guidance in game that helps a new player, the 397 page pdf manual is little or no help (once you find it) googling 'dom4 nation setup' gives lots of forum postings by those who use so many acronyms they're illegible.[e.g. EA Neif Monolith E9A1E6 D6 O3P3C3G1M3D0 - really didnt help me - though now I know the game better I can see is a helpful build suggestion]In short you really have to put work in to get to the point where the game is anything more than a turn based terrirtory domino fall game of conquest.Dominions 4 is however far more than that. Yes you can just pump troops out and spread your gods dominion by attacking and taking over all other gods territories but there is so much more here once you look. Research of spells & items to forge add a lot but other than being a wider available choice you get similar tech tree approaches in many other games. Adding the divine to the game is a somewhat new, interesting and brilliant twist - the aim is not global military dominion but instead for your god to spread his dominion to the world, to spread belief in your god to the exclusion of all other gods. Belief can cross borders stepping right over a turtled mass of troops in a pinch point.As a suggestion:1. find the online pdf manual (linked in guides) play the 9 turn by rote guide to controls (found somewhere about 90 pages in interspersed with irrelevant and unhelpful history of how the game was made and waffle about the designers inspiration for the game.2. Play a Late Age (LA) Nation called Man, dont worry about nation / god setup on a small map against any random land based nation, dont research anything / forge any items just work with longbowmen to get the feel of the game.3. Play an Early Age (EA) Nation called Metlican. Google some setups but the one that works for me is :Demilich (Imprisoned): Water 4 Death 9 Nature 9, Dominion 8 Order 3 Sloth 3 Heat 2 Growth 2 Misfortune 2 Drain 2Set a commander to the spells Blessing / Divine Blessing and work with Jaguar Warriors.Use these to learn the game to the point where you feel comfortable experimenting & understand the forum post acronyms you'll find from google.I hope you enjoy the game as much as I have!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												This is a deep turn-based strategy title that's about spreading you your deity’s religious power through conquest and proselytizing. It’s a fantasy title and has something like 10,000+ unique spells between the different factions.Your deity’s avatar (pretender god) will appear at some point, which you preset. You pick the time period you want to start the game in, which will affect technology and available starting factions. You need a pretty hefty system to run it at max fps, there’s a lot of calculations that go on in the background. The graphics aren’t spectacular either way. Combat is hands off. You set the tactics and formations your commanders will use, as well as the dispositions of the units. Spying will help you know how to set your tactics. Proselytizing will give you advantages as the faith of the locals will change advantages. Watching post-combat reports and fact sheets will be hugely beneficial on how you change your tactics for the next conflict with that particular army. As you learn the game it becomes even deeper. The dev’s made it so it’s easy to make your own maps, and the community has uploaded quite a few between Dominions 3-4. The game does allow you to build up territories that you control. You can also search for places of power, which give you advantages. Research will allow you to have access to more powerful spells (and better craftables), which allow you to more fully utilize the power of your casters (individual units have caps on capabilities and with what kinds of spells they can utilize; it’s all part of the strategy).I’ve enjoyed this title, and if you like strategy games this is a title you will like. It’s from a small dev team, which has a long heritage of solid strategy/tactical games. If you buy it from the dev’s website (or their publisher) you will get the DRM-free version as well as a steam key. Desura was also giving you a key if you had a license from the dev (I’m not sure if they still do or if Desura is a healthy company at this point).

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												" I had a vampire uprising in one of my desert provinces so my merman had to team up with my local barbarian cavalry cause all the oni were busy fighting down south" - My explination of what was going on in one of my games.A fantastic 4x game that is rather simple to play once you get past the overwhelming text and barely present GUI, however should you choose to jump down the rabbit hole there is a lot of depth for you to find in all of the different civilizations as well as the numerous gods you can combine with them. Magic only adds to the complexity as you research a variety of spells in different "Schools" of magic but even then its unlikely you're faction will even favor all of the spells you research in a single campaign causing numerous spells to go essentially unused unless you can get some foreign troops skilled in that element to aid you. All in all if you can get past the graphics and the fact that you will have to teach yourself everything about this game as it gives you almost nothing to start with, you're gonna have one heck of a ride.Pros:+Numerous Factions+Deep Magic System+God customization ensures that even playing the same faction will be different+Easily Moddable+Sieges, Assassinations, and screaming wild women clawing out the eyes of your enemies+ Map size and game settings allow you to set up games that'll last anywhere from 2-20 hoursCons:- No tutorial on top of the game being wordy and poorly organized- GUI is functional (once you are used to it its not so bad) but is not intuitive and it can be difficult to find info at times- A whole lot to manage at once (turn-based and meant to be played slow and methodically, the multiplayer can even utilize Play-By-Email, so not a con for everyone but not everyone's cup of tea)

												This game has a lot of history and charm to it, and has a ridiculous amount of depth. Like, a 400 page manual's worth of depth. He was slain trying to take the Throne of Stars by a skeletal army commanded by 3 necromancers, but was resurected by his priests and enacted vengeance on the necromancers. His people, the Nazca, conquered the Atlanteans and Ichthyids, and with them wrested control of the last two Thrones of Ascension from the Tritons. His high priest Quizquiz claimed the Throne of Stability in his name, and the Sun God himself walked beneath the water and sat on the Throne of Ice, cementing his rule as the One True God against the frost giants and their pretender of the Hungry Forest.If that was at all entertaining to read, you'll like this game. I promise.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												I have played Dominions since the original, and have always enjoyed it.  It is one of my favorites, and I come back to it every few months.  Each version has brought improvements, and 4 is the best so far.  I don't mind spending the money for the new versions, because supporting a durable indy developer is priceless.There are numerous races to be played, and they are all very different.  There is a ton of replay value, just trying out new factions and learning their strengths and weaknesses.  It also makes you a better player, since those factions appear in other playthroughs as your rivals, and there is nothing like knowing your enemies intimately.This very diversity of strategies leads to the game's major limitation: the AI opponent presents a very weak challenge.  It simply isn't built to compete at your level, so you will get to the point where playing against the computer is like playing against a young child: the only way to create a challenge is to let it cheat gratuitously.  Higher difficulty levels simply give the AI more and more bonuses, rather than kicking in more cleverness or sophistication.  I recognize that game AI is still a fantasy, but this is a fantasy game after all. ;)I am confident that human players would provide that competition; however, I have never had the flexibility to commit to that kind of long social engagement.  I will continue to dream of a day when the computer opponent is as satisfying as a person.

												Dominions 4 is an amazing game with alot of depth, don't let the simple graphics and rather obtuse UI tell you otherwise. There are hundreds of units, hundreds of spells and thousands of strategies to use to become the ultimate god. Every nation is different, from the Dominion of Ermor which kills the populace within it's domain in order to fuel it's undead armies, the fire children Abysians which are wreathed in flame and burn their way through their enemies.Even choosing a pretender is a process that can take 10 minutes, each having different stats and magical potential. Some can be built as towering titan bruisers that crush armies beneath their boots, some are powerful wizards that can plunge the entire world into darkness or make their enemies lungs fill with water.Seriously, put a little bit of time into this game and you will not regret it.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												Great game if you love strategy games. Very deep with lots of replayability!More hours into this game than any other game at least since steam has been tracking it. I also played on desura for at least a hundred hours. I think a good measure of a strategy game is how many hours you see logged for peoples reviews on here. You are a god! You can make you're own god and pick from many different styles of nations, and fight against other gods,It takes a while to figure out how everything works, since the game is so deep. You can keep upping the difficulty in many ways as you learn how to take advantage of everything you can do. With low difficulty you can have fun before you know all the ins and outs, I would recommend looking at some of the user guides. I haven't really checked out the multiplayer as it seems like it takes a long time, and my play time is sporadic and hard for me to plan.Custom map editor and generator. There are a lot of user made maps to download, and you can generate and modify your own. Also a lot of user created empires, but there is so much already in the game I haven't even downloaded any of it!You can outfit special or summoned units, or thugs as they're refered to. Sea Troll King, many types of demons, liches, giants. It adds an RPG element to the game.One of my favorite games ever!

content:
Posted: April 16
												I love this game. So much so that i bought it a second time here on steam for convenience. There are many maps in the vanialla edition, and more can be downloaded from the community (those people are the best). The game itself has high re-playability, extreme depth, loads of factions, spells and Items in three distinct eras. Characters can be modified with names, equipment and spells. If your hero becomes experienced he will get a hall of fame bonus which are awesome. To equip a hero can be easy, or you can make it into a science of stacking abilities. Some heroes die if they meet a single foe, others can invade continents alone. You and your game knowledge decide which is which. I have spent hundreds of hours on the third edition, (and the fourth) and the forth has added alot of new content. I reccomend this game if you like to tinker, roleplay, care more about depth than graphics and be aware that sound in vanilla is a bit bothersome with some units (but there are mods that fix that).

content:
Posted: April 16
												I am certain most of my points would have been covered already by other reviewers, but I wanted to say good things about this game anywayPros:Complex strategy, involving macro management of your provinces/troops, magical utilities eg summoning/crafting, spreading dominion via priests and temples, as well as setting up troop formations and battle ordersVery unique God/Dominion system. Your god can be a statue, giant people (including a naked woman), Odin, Santa, a dragon, or a pile of bones (muffled doot), and many others (even just regular mage-dudes). Your god can specialise in magical paths, or spend points in making your religion/dominion a certain way, or a combination of bothMagic is quite varied in its use (if your god is a statue, he can't move, but you can teleport him somewhere else, or you can summon things, or just throw regular ol' favourites like fireballs and lightning bolts)Cool ancient human mythos setting with many different races, with each being either slightly or very different from each other (races that use unique mechanics exist such as aquatic, underground, or undead races)Very responsive 'controls' (not a lot of waiting. when you click, something happens immediately)Skellington race produces skellingtons by using in-game necromancy instead of just training them (10/10 very immersive)Pretty cool, proportionate artstyle if you look past the pixelsAlthough complex, LOTS of information can be found in the UI and its many menusCons:Often feels like going the cheaper units over the expensive ones is a bad ideaMorale seems arbitrary sometimes, and since all fights are auto-calculated it can be frustrating to loseSome information seems hidden or unintuitive Way too easy to click the exit button during multiplayer (literally 5 of us in a group have all done it multiple times)Sound effects are pretty lulzyWhat the ♥♥♥♥ is this UI tho srslyFriends complain about the complexity sometimesNot enough skellingtonsOverall, for this type of game, I'm very impressed with it and give it 8/10The terrible UI and graphics can be forgiven in favour of how much I enjoy the detail and complexity of the strategy, of which there is much of, but at the same time more work could have been done on them.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												If Dungeons and Dragons was turned into an epic turn-based strategy game that was just "plain awesome," it would be Dominions 4.  Create your own God and play one of over a dozen unique civilizations as they progress from the time of legends in the early era all the way to the days of conventional medieval warfare in the late era.  Races are heavily influenced by popular culture and real world history/civilizations.  You'll find obscure references to Conan the Barbarian, H.P. Lovecraft, Hercules,etc... all the way to Vlad the Impaler and so on.Personally, I like to raise forth a sea of mindless thralls to serve as the limitless buffer for my vampire aristocracy.  Large urban population centers are soon converted into blood farms where my illuminati spies and sorcerors sacrifice virgins by the hundreds for their dark lord and master.   As my power becomes complete, the Sun is removed from the sky with the global spell "UTTERDARK" as the world plunges into perpetual night.  Crops wither and die as world economies follow suit.  Fear of starvation is replaced by genuine terror of what now roams in great numbers through the unlit countryside.  The currency of gold is replaced by human blood that grows scarcer by the day untl only the monsters remain.Needless to say, yeah, this game is pretty cool.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												This is  fun game.  I got it for 20 bucks on sale.  I loved all the ideas but was turned off by the super outdated graphics.  Even with crap graphics the game is super fun and addictive.  If you have played eu4. ck2 or games like it you will feel at home playing on a map.  Where this game differs from the other is how much you can customize characters and make armies.  In one turn i sent an astral arrow into the heart of an enemy commander, summoned 2 different animal group to fight and 250 men to storm a castle of an enemies capitol province.    The "bad Graphics" thing really comes from the battle recap.  Before the turn ends you can set different orders for your armies.  At the end of the turn everything gets added up.  You can then watch a replay of the battle to get an idea of how your strategies worked out.  Yes its ugly but its helpful and eventually helps immerse you into your own little story.   If you enjoy grand strats, rpg and games where you get to have a GOD avatar this is a game to get.

number of helpful: 27 of 57 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												NOTE: There will be no TL;DR version of this review. To quote Maxi’s review “If you really usually jump for TLDRs don't bother getting the game.”I want to be clear about this, I love this game. I think it's great fun. I've sunk around 100 hours into Dominions 3, with another 70 into Dom 4. I think Dom 4 is a flat out improvement from its predecessor, and given the choice I would chose to play Dom 4 every time. That said this is not really a game that I could recommend to my friends, let alone to some stranger on the Internet. To start off the graphics are old fashioned and I know a LOT of people who will turn up their nose at a game just because it doesn't look pretty. If the idea of some simple sprites moving across a painted background isn't your idea of an acceptable battle animation then turn around and walk the other way. The combat may also be something that turns people off. The combat works through a scripting element, something that was designed in part so that players could engage in multiplayer through a play by email style (if that doesn't show you that the game might have some antiquated design ideas hanging around, I don't know what will). This means that you as a player cannot engage in combat in real time, it happens between game turns and you receive a summary and video of what happened in the combat while you were away. You set up your units, tell them where to go and what to do (within certain limitations of course. You cannot, for instance, order your archers to stop firing if friendlies come into danger of being shot, nor can you order your troops to wait more or less than two turns before charging headlong into the enemy), and then they handle everything by themselves without any more input by you. This can sometimes make you feel as though you are being cheated, like if you didn't get a very good scout report and the enemy wound up having cavalry you weren’t prepared for that decimate your troops with their lances. Maybe if you could alter orders on the fly, you would have ordered your mages to cast a spell to stop or slow the cavalry instead of trying to buff your own troops. I find this to just be part of the game, and I enjoy the strategic fetters it places upon my gameplay. Some people, though, may not. This, I think, is the main point of contention one will have with the game. If you can find yourself enjoying the combat, then you'll probably be fine. That said, there are a smattering of more tedious issues that can still turn you away.One such issue is micromanagement. On a small map with one to four other nations, you can manage your little empire without too much of a struggle. If you try to play on a large map with 12+ nations, you'll be working through a micromanagement slog the likes of which you may have not even comprehended before. If you are playing as a nation with heavy troops capable of only moving one province per turn, may the Pantokrator help you. Add in the fact that the UI is not great, and you might not even know how to do the thing that you want to do. I love micro (I play vanilla Dwarf Fortress as well), and I don't mind referring to the manual when I forget how to do a little thing like copy orders or make a mage cast the same spell every month, but if you aren't willing to find those little time saving things the micro can weigh you down even more quickly.The last detractor is the AI, and this is the only real reason I'll ever take a break from the game. Dominions is the kind of game that was always developed with multiplayer in mind, and I think that the game gives players a lot of tools to build, execute, and adapt to different strategies. While I haven't played any multiplayer in my time with the game, I have seen several games and read a lot of the theorycrafting involved. While that isn't the same as playing a MP game, I think it gives me a measure of insight into how the game can function differently in MP as opposed to SP. Sadly, the AI isn't very good at using a lot of those strategic tools designed for human players. For example, let's say you have two kinds of units that can "hold the line" and buy time for either your ranged units or mages to kill the enemy. The first are heavily armored pikemen capable of repelling, and thus negating, enemy melee attacks. The second are heavy infantry with a shield, these ones better prepared to tank volleys of arrows. While I can build both and adapt which one I need depending on my opponent, I see the AI often just building one or the other and fielding that against all opponents regardless of attrition rate, or building both in equal numbers (which admittedly isn’t a very bad idea if you haven’t seen what your opponent's army looks like, but if I march in with a cadre of longbowmen maybe some more shield guys would be prudent). I have seen the AI do some cool things, I was foiled often in my early days by some spell I didn't even know about, but after a while I find myself wishing that the AI could bring something new and exciting to the table (Master enslave. Just once, I want to have to worry about Master Enslave in single player). Of course, this doesn't keep me away for long. The AI is fun enough to face at high difficulties that I enjoy myself, and after a while I just think of a new exciting thing that I want to try, so I don't care if the AI isn't amazing. All in all, none of these things stop me from loving this game. I walk away from time to time, but I always find myself coming back, or even just thinking about the game when I'm taking a break from it. If none of the things I mentioned sound like they would bother you, then I would encourage you to go read some multiplayer threads, watch lets play videos, or in the best case scenario ask a friend of yours who has the game to let you try it. While I jumped into the Dominions series blindly and wound up loving it, I know that I'm exceptional in that regard. I don't think this game appeals to the average gamer, or even to the average strategy gamer. I think this is a game for the kind of person who was never bothered by the Dwarf Fortress UI or “fun,” who always thought the diplomatic options in Civilization were just there for babies that didn't have the guts to earn their victory on the point of their spear, who likes the idea of a world in which no one is ever the "good guy," and who doesn't mind playing a game that might not be balanced if that imbalance allows one to tell a better story. Most importantly though, it is a game for someone who doesn't mind gambling 35$ on a game they may very well not like. If that doesn't sound like you, then that's fine. But if you're the special kind of crazy for whom it does, I'll be waiting here for you. Just you try to take my throne away from me. I dare you.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												I highly recommend this game to any strategy enthusiasts, or fans of mythology, out there. I'll go ahead and get the (tiny) amount of criticism out of the way - the game has an unusual user interface, and targeted selection of units can be especially tedious at times. With that detail out of the way, I only have good things to say about Dominions 3. The writing in the game is top-notch, and very immersive. You often have to play multiple races to get a fuller picture of the history, but it's rich and satisfying once you piece it together. The Tuatha and the Fomorian Giants are a good example. The game plays in a traditional fashion concerning territories and the movement of agents and armies, much like other turn-based games. However, to locate the useful goodies in a territory, you'll have to cultivate a few powerful mages among your commanders, to find hidden sites that can provide mana gems, unique and powerful units for recruitment, or special effects, once unearthed. You'll need them (and magi once again) for the forging of magical items to equip your agents, priests, mages, generals, prophet, and your Pretender God. But the true meat of the game is in spreading your dominion (aka faith) across the map. It is the source of your power, and since it can flow into enemy territoy, it can also hamper their efforts to withstand your (inevitable) attack. Be sure to build lots of temples in your own honor! Put those puny mortal mages to work researching powerful magic that can affect the whole world. Turn day to perpetual night, bring on and endless winter, summon hurricanes, kill someone from anywhere in the world, dispach the flying monkeys to pluck away some unfortunate soul! Last Pretender God standing wins the prize - true Godhood. Sounds simple, right? Think again. It's a deep and complex game, and can be quite the challenge at times. So join in the fun, weave your own epic tale! Smash vampires with giants, ♥♥♥♥♥ queens (yes, its a real Pretender) with a midget masher, or run from Cthulu! It's all in there, and waiting for you! Order now!

												Do you want to play a game ? How about global thermanl nuclear war?  No , well if not I got this one about fake gods trying to control the world and eliminate that competition. I think you can play one of about 30 very diferent empires . There are hundreds of units and spells and  each player gets to create their own unique pretender god.   It's the fourth one in the series. If you've played the previous games the major new feature you will notice is the new thrones of ascension. These work like vicotry points that give you empire wide bonuses. They come in 3 sizes and you can configure how many are on the map and how many it takes to win the game. If you were looking for something like master of magic I think this is about the closest you'll get at this time.  Enjoy .

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												This game is so deep that it will never leave you bored.The graphics are insanely simple, but all of the units are drawn. Sometimes it is hard to distinguish the units that look similar. Only the small differences make it clear which unit is which. But the random map generator draws so beautifully that it lets you forget every problem you might have with the simplicities.The music is terrific! You play them over and over hundreds of times and it still never gets old.The magic system is very deep. There are paths and schools with over 800 spells! Much of them are summoning, but there are rituals and combat spells alike, including global spells.The units are abundant, I have never seen a game before that has so many units in it, with detailed descriptions for each. By the way, the whole game is based on mythology.I can only recommend this game to others. Discover everything that was not written here, the journey will be exhilarating!

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												While I've only sunk in about 4 hours of playtime when I wrote this, I sank in about 2 - 3 hours studying the massive 295 page manual (half of it's just spell / unit statistics, so only 120 pages or so of reading). While the process of reading this manual was a bit oppressive and a rather large time investment just to start playing, from what I can see is there is a game with an incredible amount of depth and replayability. Just from the start you get random worlds and the ability to craft your own "pretender" (basically a demigod) and then explore with the aim of conquering. There is espionage, assassinations, and management of your territories. Perhaps the only thing that's missing in my mind is diplomacy (it's a war game) but I for one never have really explored those aspects in games like this so nothing was really missing.The difficulty of this title is steep, at least to someone like myself. What's good is that if you read the manual, you should be able to get several hours of playtime and experimentation before you start to get undermined by other nations. This gives you a good shot at your first playthrough to get a grasp on the basics before starting a hopefully more successful campaign.The graphics are abhorrent, I won't lie, so if you need at least poor graphics to be satisfied I'd stay away. Graphics however are sacrificed for depth which to me, is far more important. There is so much complexity (but in a good way) to each aspect of the game: your towns (buildings, defense levels, dominion, etc.), the terrain, your soldiers (commanders, unit  types, formations, leadership, items), and a robust magic system as well. I could go on, but I already fear that this review is a bit incoherent as there really is a lot to say about the game. [B}TLDR[/B]Pros+Great Depth of Gameplay, incredible opportunities for strategy.+Great Customization: Province Management, Commanders, Unit Types / Organization, Orders, etc.+Very Replayable due to custom game modes.+Tons of multiplayer options including classic favorites like Play By E-Mail and Hotseat+Rich in Lore and Mythology based upon real life mythology.+Tons of Unit Types, Spells, and ItemsCons-Clunky UI, not reading / following the tutorial will make it very diffiuclt to get used to the controls.-Incredibly huge manual (295 pages, of which 120 pages are essential reading) that you really must read if you don't want to spend many frustrating hours of trial and error.-Absolutely hideous graphics, they really aren't good at all. The game is purportedly very moddable and that's something I will explore as I get bored of the stock game as well!

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												Not for the faint of heart, this strategy game will require multiple play throughs and attempts to grasp all of the mechanics. It is feature rich with so many different units, spells, items... the learning curve makes it brutal but rewarding when you start understanding how to affect the world. I think my favorite aspect is creating leaders with unique equipment and casting abilities. These leaders will be generals for your basic unit and can enchance their combat abilties. As a game progresses, you will move up the different magic aspects which unlock more combat casting and summoning unit. You will also be able to pick up rare units to supplement your faction. The game is just huge. If you want a game that will challenge you and offer high replayability check it out. I would suggest reading through the massive user manual otherwise you will be over your head immediately.

number of helpful: 17 of 37 people (46%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												My actual play time is over a thousand hours as I have only recently registed it on Steam. There are three key problems with this game. The first is that the game gets boring after a while. Yes, I'm talking about multiplayer. Initially, it is exciting learning how to outwit other human players -- raid and counter raid, various strategies, spells and their counters. After a while, though, there is a serious lack of variety. There are many spells, units and items in the game, but the reality is that over 90% of them are plain bad and you'll always be restricted by a very limited selection to what is feasible/competitive.The second problem is a rather toxic community. For some reason, many people who play the game think that they are geniuses and have sky high egos. It can be really frustrating communicating with them especially if they know that they are wrong but just plain refuse to admit it. I guess that people who play this game are naturally more logical and hence think that they are smart. The third is that many multiplayer games end up dead. It is difficult to find a game where everyone is playing competitively until the end. Most of the time, someone will give up and disappear halfway through the game, resulting in his neighbour becoming stronger. Some times, people refuse to attack the leader and let him run away with the game. Some times your starting location is bad, you have no chance. In any case, it gets really frustrating when people treat the game flippantly. Winning the game can be due to plain luck since many factors are outside of your control.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												This game, made by two people, has more depth than most of the AAA strategy titles I've played.  This is not another Civ or HoMM clone; here we have a spell list that makes the tech tree of any 4x game you've played look like a post-it note.  Every single troop and item has a back story and a sprite, and every spell has a counter strategy to a counter strategy whch acts as a counter-counter-counter strategy.Unfortunately, the learning curve is sharp.  The game comes with a read-along tutorial, but nothing can prepare you for the blistering amount of options you have at your fingertips until you play the game.  A lot of the game is figuring out how your different units can behave, because unlike other games where your troops simply "move, attack, or build a structure" commanders in this game can search for blood sacrifices, preach the word of your god, cast a staggering variety of ritual spells, patrol for spies, assassinate commanders with stealthed heroic squads (I made Brock Samson and some OSI agents) and so much more.  Once you amass a healthy army, troop setup and positioning before battle is also vital.The game is also not very pretty.  The only nice thing to say about the UI is that it's functional.  No form here; you're presented with a drop-down list that looks like it came from a primitive spreadsheet document.  The backgrounds are pixelated, and the pictures of the troops look like they came from a 16 bit game, though I actually find that charming.What this game lacks in eye candy, it makes up in strategic depth.  Whether you like min-maxing or discovering new strategies on the fly, the absolutely massive toolkit this game gives players means that there is almost always a new way to screw over your opponents and be screwed yourself.  There are so many ways for players to customize their win conditions and other game settings, though this often feels like an old-school war game where the players have to commit to a solid 3-5 hour chunk of play time (though you don't have to do it all in one go because the game saves everyone's progress).  This game also makes you feel like a real deity with spells that let you do anything from creating a global hurricane, ageing the world's population supernaturally fast, or summoning elder gods to rampage indiscriminately across the continent.  There are just SO MANY ways to build your god, nation, and heroes.Also, I would like to say that this is the first game I've played in a long time where I've felt like a proper necromancer.  You're not raising a handful of skeletal minions here, oh no.  If you so choose, the entire world will wither and legions of the dead will rise from the doomed populace to do your bidding as your carrion dragon leads squads of bane knights you equipped with weeping blades of venom against your enemies.The developers patch new content in on a regular basis, and have claimed they will continue to do so for the next 2 years at the least.  If you are a strategy enthusiast who has the patience to power through a steep learning curve, this game is an absolute must-buy.To get an idea of the sheer amount of things your can summon, forge, and cast check out this site: http://larzm42.github.io/dom4inspector/

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198096885327/recommended/248510/this is my review form dom3. and dom4 is even better. I had my doubts about buying it, since the changes seemed few and not game-changing. but... once you try it, there is no going back. the best change is the manual (YES, you can improve a 300 page manual. adding another 100 pages with every unit stats), but the others are those little things that seem unimportant, but you cannot live without them once you get used to them (note: although for me, the thrones of ascension aren't THAT great. I mean, I like them for the effects and the strategy twist, but I don't really needed a new victory condition. Conquering everything seems good enough for me. but you can still do that on dom4.... )I love this. It's the largest game I have seen in terms of quality content and replayability. and one of my all-time favorites. I totally see myself playing this a few years from now. And that's much to say. a side note: don't start a map with too many opponents (~10), it will last VERY long (my first map on dom4 lasted for about 75 hours..... )oh. and about the AI. it may not be a challenge for experienced players... but you will easily reach a few hundreds of hours before that. I mean, on normal difficulty, I still have to be very careful or I'll easily lose... just buy it. no need to even wait for a sale, even for full price is completely worth it. PS: I have something like 30hours more than steam says. but steam crashes every now and then. and my hours vanish. sigh. PPS: well, if you are not sure... there's a demo on the illwinter page. Or at least there was for dom3.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												After 18 Hours of digging into Dominions 4 and playing through 5 different games , I can safely say this game did not come through for my inner strategy gamer.Major Cons-1- Cookie Cutter Strategies Included - There are a lot of spells but nations are so cookie cuttered into a particular set of paths that it is hard to develop more than a few strategies for a race. Unlike in games like Master of Magic where you can easily pick the spells you want to cast with your nation all the time to develop a theme or strategy that enhances the weak points or strengths of your race. Now, you can design your pretender to cast any spells you want. But this is a strategic game and your caster can only be in one place at one time and can usually only cast one of the big spells and then he/she/it is knocked unconscious. Its not very fun and does not make a lot of sense to me.2- Low Strategic Value/Adaptability offered by units - As with spells, each race has a handful of units that are great at certain things but there was not a lot of strategic decision making offered by the units. After you get used to constructing a line of spearmen who can push back units or are fronted by trampling war elephants/cavalry, there is little to be done adapting to an opponent. I wished spells or different units could respond better to the how the game changes on the combat scene, but it does not offer any adaptibility.3- The Strategy Game that makes you work - This is a big one for me. I don't mind researching unit stats and comparing them to each other. I really dont mind reading a 400 page manual to find out how each of the different nations function on a strategic level. But trying to figure out what spells you can and can't cast and trying to plan for it...and then just trying to see if it is even worth it because it feels like half of the spells are worthless in most situations ( aka, only affecting the weak♥♥♥♥♥caster with a melee damage buff...wtf...i guess this would be only for pretenders), is just frustrating.So overall, I gave Dominions 4 a pretty fair shake. It has so much that would have been fun with a bit more tweaking and forethought, but the warfare is too one dimensional and cookie cutter. Not recommended.

number of helpful: 54 of 116 people (47%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												After 18 Hours of digging into Dominions 4 and playing through 5 different games , I can safely say this game did not come through for my inner strategy gamer.Major Cons-1- Cookie Cutter Strategies Included - There are a lot of spells but nations are so cookie cuttered into a particular set of paths that it is hard to develop more than a few strategies for a race. Unlike in games like Master of Magic where you can easily pick the spells you want to cast with your nation all the time to develop a theme or strategy that enhances the weak points or strengths of your race. Now, you can design your pretender to cast any spells you want. But this is a strategic game and your caster can only be in one place at one time and can usually only cast one of the big spells and then he/she/it is knocked unconscious. Its not very fun and does not make a lot of sense to me.2- Low Strategic Value/Adaptability offered by units - As with spells, each race has a handful of units that are great at certain things but there was not a lot of strategic decision making offered by the units. After you get used to constructing a line of spearmen who can push back units or are fronted by trampling war elephants/cavalry, there is little to be done adapting to an opponent. I wished spells or different units could respond better to the how the game changes on the combat scene, but it does not offer any adaptibility.3- The Strategy Game that makes you work - This is a big one for me. I don't mind researching unit stats and comparing them to each other. I really dont mind reading a 400 page manual to find out how each of the different nations function on a strategic level. But trying to figure out what spells you can and can't cast and trying to plan for it...and then just trying to see if it is even worth it because it feels like half of the spells are worthless in most situations ( aka, only affecting the weak♥♥♥♥♥caster with a melee damage buff...wtf...i guess this would be only for pretenders), is just frustrating.So overall, I gave Dominions 4 a pretty fair shake. It has so much that would have been fun with a bit more tweaking and forethought, but the warfare is too one dimensional and cookie cutter. Not recommended.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Civilization maps & resources + Risk troop stacking + D&D RPG Items and Spells + Rome Total War troop combinations.What do you get? Dominions 4!I played a game for 3 hours and started to feel the burn of losing.Where I started not knowing the map is continuously scrolling until "mid" game. Then I realized, I could've won this a long time ago, I stacked my troops of minotars and centaurs, along with my "pretend god" and marched them on the enemy castle, little did I know, that pretend god can die, and calling the god back takes AGES! So I thought, big whoop, I got biggest army and there's only 4 squares left to take, I got all their forts.Well guess the ♥♥♥♥ what?They rule by politics, aka dominions, candle figures, and I saw the white candles turn black, and plenty, even though I held physical victories, they spread like communism in 1940s. So I pooled all my gold, hired all the mercenaries, and still got my butt kicked. Lesson learned, don't put your "pretend god" on the frontlines, doesn't matter how decked out, how much spells and how much planning you put in him, he still needs an army.Every general can be deployed with a personal strategy, if you don't like to micromanage (clicking repeated things a lot), this game isn't for you. Also you can claim resource points, build a fort, hold it down.If you like civilization, rome total war, CK2 (combat side), dungeons and dragons dice rolls on hit, you got yourself a dominion.I'm still :salt:y

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17
												One word: Confusion.If you don't watch youtube videos on this game, there is really a greater chance than not you will be absolutely clueless as to what you're doing or why you're doing it.Such a depthy strategy game with deep dynamics in terms of units, races, and gods... honestly so unique that it makes me cringe to put this game into the depths of games I will never have the time to touch.(this is coming from a guy who has put about 4 years out of 27 into time played in video games.)There is no tutorial, hints, or anything even close to it integrated into the game; the UI is probably the worst i've ever encountered too, add the two features of inevitably doomed to confusion and a UI from the mid-80's interacting with AI from 2010's, it's a mess.  The game is really picky and precise on how you do things too and it's because of the insanely poor UI.  Processes  like "drag and drop" are rendered as "drag, drop, lock, assign, instruct" and if you don't do exactlly that, the unit you're assigning will just go back to their original spot before you dragged them.  To make matters worse, that very situation is intensified further by an unintuitive UI, in this case, it won't warn you in ANYWAY that your intended action was unsuccessful - instead it will just put the character back after you leave the screen.My problems with this game start at the most basic levels and this has been a factor before which i've overcome and have enjoyed myself a great game because of my abilitiy to understand it - but every little thing in this game is a hastle, and at the end of the day it's just not intrigueing enough.25/10 - lore factor 0/10 - frustrated beyond recognition

number of helpful: 9 of 24 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												Let me throw my hands up and say I've never played any of the previous titles. I openly admit that. What I want to know is how at no point in four renditions of this game have they introduced a way to manage buildings more effectively than one province at a time. It took me nearly 20 minutes to complete a turn, and then I realised this was on a small map. I can't even concieve of how long it would take to complete a single game, and not because of any kind of "gameplay", simply hours and hours of clicking the same thing in menus. A building queue. That's all it would take. Let me queue up multiple buildings to be built, like you can with infantry. If I have 20 provinces, I have to go back and build every single building individually 20 times. Every castle, tower, walls, etc. I realized in my short time with this game I had spent about 50~60% of it not actually "playing". I was spending it clicking "build this". I could go into MSPaint, write the word "build this" and click it a few hundred thousand times and get pretty much the same experience. The actual game? The infantry battles, the heroes, the actual "PLAYING" part? It's awesome. It was really fun! It's really in depth, a lot of tactics involved, and I loved it! But how does this game not have a better management system!? HOW?! How has not a single fan of this game told the developers "Hey you know what would be a good idea? The ability to queue up buildings." How can I possibly reccomend a game where I would completely cut out 50% of the "gameplay" if I could? It's horrendous. It's inhuman. I genuinely am concerned for anyone who plays this game regularly. How do you possibly do that for hours and hours on end?

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												The game has a board game style and deep systems.  The various factions are diverse and customizable.  The basic premise is amusing and the overall flow of the game seems well designed.  Where the problem for me lies is the combat.   Battles are automated and the player can view the results as a replay after they occur.  After spending a fair amount of time in several games as differently designed factions setting up squads, I can say that I have no clue what does or doesn't work.  My strong armies were defeated by what seemed to be weaker ones with ease.  Parsing the combat logs didn't help me figure things out.  I read the actual game manual, which is quite interesting in and of itself, but it didn't seem to help with this.  The in game combat probably would have worked better as a turn based, player-controlled system.  I think perhaps the developers avoided that as they wanted a board game style that didn't get bogged down with combat.  The result is that, without extensive forum-diving, the average player will end up simply building large armies and throwing them around with no preconception of what will be effective.On the other hand, the game developer continually updates the game and there are avid players from whom one might receive help.  If the game were about half its current price of 34.99 USD, I would recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 17 people (12%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												When I saw this game I thought I hit the jackpot, really poor graphics with really great reviews.  There seemed to be awesome depth, with tons of units, races, leaders, status modifiers, spells, and victory conditions.  My first game I picked a magic heavy leader with a race balanced between magic and combat.  I left faith at the wayside and pursued magic early on.  Magic is very costly to develop, and gives very little back, not to mention the high cost when you do use it.  I switched to being combat heavy and did well, though I was still trying to grasp all the nuances of battle (it has tons of options, but is ultimately autocalced).  the enemy had a delayed start, and when they did come unto the scene I beat them at every turn, though my casualties got higher with each battle.  As I started to clinch my victory I suddenly lost.  I was out faithed, and my leader suddenly died due to such.  so for my second game I sat down and tried to figure out a better approach.  I realized that just by dumping all my points into faith, and picking a race that had good priests I would win without having to win many battles, or develop any magic.  I picked a combat heavy leader, but maxed out faith, and picked the race with the best priests.  Early on I was too aggressive and suffered a lot of losses.  In the end I was a push over in every area, except faith (which i was being very innefficiant at), and I won easily.The problem is that faith is cheap and easy, and there is no way to remove it as a victory condition.  Have a low faith side, and end up dead quick.  Have a High faith side and almost auto win.  Don't get me wrong, the faith mechanics other than your leader insta dying are great.  In fact most aspects of this game is great, however all of it means nothing due to the current death by faith mechanic.  balancing all enemies to have the same faith is the only way to actually use the majority of the game's mechanics, which is easiest to do via multiplayer with humans.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I bought this game because it stated it was multiplayer co-op. Technically that may be true, but it is no simple task to play multiplayer. It is misleading to say it is a multiplayer game, as for most people that will be almost impossible to work out the network configuration. For a start you need a separate instance of the game running a server. You can't do that on your own machine or you get a bad packet error (and that's after working out how to run two instances). There's no real help for it, so the game is now essentially useless except single player, which would be fine, but that's not why I bought it.

												i think this might be a good game at heart but i cannot recommend it as some stuff that should be obvious is not (like how do i reinforce). why might this be a good game? because its gameplay  ideas make a lot of sense and are obviously the result of much tweaking over a long series of games. however the game does not do very much to introduce you , which is not just bad, its a lazy oversight for such complex games. you can probably invest a ridiculous amount of time to get this game but i don't think its worth it. it's a good concept though. and there are many races. you can even play as Ulm, which is nicefor fans of a particularly famous AAR of another game. there are many options. also hotseat. they did not bother with a singleplayer campaign either, which is another lazy oversight.  also the graphics suck and unlike some other people i don't think there is any technical excuse for that. just developer laziness. if you do pixel art, make sure its 'oh my god thats beautyful' pixel art. this game should just run on a 3D engine.only recommended if you have crazy amounts of time to waste.

Add in that the limited development of the provinces (you can only build three buildings - temple, lab, and fort) and lack of depth in the economy and you are left with a really detailed set of units and spells, but for battles you cannot ever control. The lack of real player control over battles and the shallow economy makes this game tedious at best.

												If you're wondering "why the negative review when he's barely got any time logged on", that would be because in the few hours I've played this (online and offline), I've seen enough to not recommend the game.I'll be brief with this review, much like the time most people would spend with this game before throwing it away. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												An awesome game for awesome people.If you are a mythology buff like I am who also happens to enjoy games like those in Sid Meier's Civilization series (or Conversely Europa Universalis/Crusader Kings), as well as nigh on Dwarf fortress level learning curves, then this is the game for you.- Preposterously deep (multiple ways to play an asthma attack inducing number of different races)- Mouth wateringly creative (A million spells of varying effects and quality)- The game really caters to the modding community. Lots of great stuff out there.- Faithfully (pun intended) retains the mythological feel of the various ancient faiths the game portrays.Let me emphasize. There is no mythological figure too obscure. There is no faith's boogeymen left unjustly translated without all their crazy weird abilities. From sorcerous glamours, to shape shifting wolves/snakes/dragons, to religion not spreading unless you sacrifice some father's daughter at the altar of good intentions.However it's not without flaws.- Civ 2 era graphics.- It's not so much a learning curve as it is a learning cliff. With poisonous thorns growing up it and a pit of sharp legos below just waiting for your to fall.- Some nations can be more than a little imbalanced (Poor EA R'lyeh comes to mind).- Pretty pricey at 'half a Triple A game sans DLC'.Bottom Line: If you've ever wanted to feel like a callous vindictive divine entity with absolutely no regard for the well being of your people beyond their immediate use for dying in your glorious name, then look no further than Doms4.It's the authentic god experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												Graphics and animations flat out suck.  That out of the way, your mileage with the art style may vary.  If you don't like looking at the battles, you can simply look at the summaries to see how your army fared.Apart from that, you have the deepest turn-based strategy game available, fourth generation and better than ever for what it offers.  Easily modifiable.  There are plenty of mods available if you know where to look (start at the Desura forums for this game).  If you don't have an imagination, this game probably isn't going to come through for your inner strategy geek.  Many of the pre-made maps are beautifully realized in a variety of art styles.The game is easy to learn, but complex.  Certain civilizations will outperform and outclass others.  The worst civilizations are there to handicap better players so that they may play with their lesser skilled friends, or simply for the challenge.There's multiplayer mode, which is the preferred way to play the game for many.  The AI isn't perfect for those who prefer single-player, but there are ways of meta-gaming if you want to challenge yourself solo.I'd recommend this game for anyone who can see past the game's flaws.  Perhaps wait for a sale and put this on your wishlist, but know that this game doesn't go on sale often.  If you do go full price, know that you're supporting a good indie developer that provides support for their games years after they're released.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												You are a god, one of a pantheon of many.  The Pantokrator, your Zeus, has for whatever reason gone AWOL, so like any good subservient god, you and your entire pantheon try to usurp his throne in his absense in a divine battle royale to claim the world, inevitably tearing it apart in the process.Underneath the simple, almost retro 2.5d graphics, the clunky user interface, and all of the strange idiosyncracies in this game lies an extremely deep and varied turn based strategy game.  You begin as a patron god of one about 50 nations, each with a rich history, backstory, and set of quirks, and through your loyal believers, you take out the other gods by converting his believers, running them down with their military might, or by claiming enough thrones of ascension on the map.  Along the way, you use diplomacy and magic to gain every advantage you can, right up to and including casting spells that bend reality in your favor.This is the only game I have ever played where I've had armies of naked women fight on my behalf, made trees sing praises in my name, turned the earth into a desolate wasteland in like ten different ways, stole the sun out of the sky, been a sun with arms, befriended water, and made a knight that lives in a coat pocket that lives on a diet of lint.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												The German kingdom of Ulm knew what had to be done. After several stinging defeats to the Giants, their once proud realm stood on the edge of defeat. To the southwest, Hochmeister Sangerhausen, the leader of the Black Templars had slowly but surely secured Roskva from the slavic heathens of Bogarus to the south. Soon, these fools would see the light of Ulm. They would see the light of their true God. He knows if you are sleeping; he knows if you're awake; he knows if you've been bad or good, so be good for goodness sake.For when you are bad, as these slavs had been in the eyes of our Lord, he will come for you. He is KRAMPUS, THE GREAT HORNED ONE, TRUE SUCCESSOR TO THE PANTAKRATOR'S THRONE.Unfortunately, His Great finds himself in dire straights against his Giant foes. The Kingdom, however, was far too few of infantry, after having lost so many grave Ulmers by the giant scum.He knew what had to be done. "Commander," Krampus said, his voice deep and raspy, "gather every criminal you see. Then lead them in the front lines."

Posted: November 27, 2015
												The Dominions series is complex, and not wholly intuitive. With that out of the way however, it allows for a great deal of diversity for playstyles. Everything is usable for some player, there is little in plannable metagaming. Unlike a lot of strategy games, it is unlikely that someone can hard counter you from the outset. There is a huge variety of mythologies that are drawn upon and a ludicrous number of units and playable factions. I recommend this game for casual strategy fans. I would expect a degree of dislike from folks who like hard and fast predictable strategies.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												The amount of fun this game brings is huge. How long games are, how many nations you can use at one time if your modding. And the mod nations that you can find is great as well. Warning you need to know how to mod them in manually but the end recult is awesome. On a 1500 provinces map with over 50 nations in play bring so much fun its worth going through the entire game from start to finish. The mod is easily customizable on what kind of game you want to play. From how many nations you want to play with, the size of the maps, from what happens in game. Theres so much you can do, its great!I would give this game a 8 out of 10. One point loss for how hard it is to get modded in nations into the game and testing them all together takes a long time. And as well making maps and getting the out of memory crash cause its just to big to handle. And also the crashes in general because maybe your nations are outdated and you have to uncheck them from the mods selection page, and wait till that mod is updated. But you can no longer play your saved games. Another point loss because of how long it takes for mega playthroughs to be extremely long load times in between turns because the games calculating all the other nations moves, actions, new troops, and so on.Overall the game is fun and at least worth playing once in your life time to see just how big a game can be and how unique one can be as well.
