number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												This might be The best strategy game I have ever played. Can recommend to anyone looking for good strategy game with fantasy twist.Amount of lore is epic - I have spent hours just reading manual and planning how to play with different nations, gods and dominions settings. Game is complex but still easy to start; even if you can't remember all spell effects and such - usually everything makes sense. Casting storm makes it hard to fly in combat, or shoot arrows. Rain will cause more fatigue to casters using fire magic.Moving in world map is turn based and battles are resolved automatically, you just set unit formations and script spells for mages (not necessery, AI does mostly good job). Watching these battles after each turn is probably best way to learn game mechanics.You can see stats for all units and there are many. Units gets older and old age makes you more vulnerable to diseases and injuries. Off course this in not issue if your units are demons or undead. or lifeless.I have played this since Dom III and AI is constantly getting better. It gives very good challenge, even though there are tactics it cannot counter well. There are many very different nations and tons of units, but game is still well balanced. Micromanagement with end game and large maps can be issue, especially with blood nations. Much of this depends how you play. If you have lots of commanders with equipped items, supply chain managament can take time.

Despite its dated UI and obscure controls, this is one of the few 4X games that allows you to go wild with whatever strategy you can think of. Want to field a horde of bloodthirsty eagle men that explodes violently on death? Check. Want to field an army of steel-wielding centaurs that adopted the ways of men? There's one for you. Want to cover the field in fire and lava and all the other nasties you can think of? You can do that easily. The list goes on.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												The game is a seemingly straightforward fantasy war-game.  Recruit troops, set formations and unit orders, move army into neighbouring provinces.  You do not control the battles themselves, you can only watch the battles to see if your orders worked or not and adjust your orders for next time.  Rinse and repeat.  Your build options are castles (allow recruitment of national troops in province – otherwise limited to the usually poor natives), temples (spread your faith – prereq to recruit holy units) and labs (prereq to mage recruitment, allow research, magic item forging and rituals in the province).   This game does not have a learning curve.  It's a learning minefield.  This charming game looks deceptively simple but it's subtleties and complexities hide underfoot ready to trip you up, especially as magic research progresses and options open up and the game shows it's true colours and depth.  There's an asymmetry to the game as the nations can play very differently, with 20+ nations in each era  (3 era's) giving lots of options of play styles.  For a new player it can be a bit daunting and it will take a while to find which nations you find fun but there should be a few in each era to suit.    A good game for single player, a great game for PBEM multi-player.  The biggest flaw in this game is the AI cannot handle all the complexities of the magic system, either to use it against you or to counter your own gambits.  Trade is non-existent and diplomacy is limited to either the AI is attacking you or not.  Still, you'll still get enough mileage out of single player to make this a worthwhile purchase but be warned, once you've played multi-player it's hard to go back.  So much of the joy of this is the inter-player diplomacy, ganging up on other players (and preventing them from doing the same), misinformation and saying nice doggy until you can summon a big enough stick.  Ideally by sacrificing virgins.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												I spend now 20 hours into this game and have to agree with everzone that the game is great strategy. There wasn't a true tutorial by todays standards, but that's no problem for someone, who doesn't like to explore. Now let's get to the crucial point. ...20 hours into the game and I spend most of it yet to create my own map (mostly INGAME, only 3 hours outgame). So what happened? After watching the map  editor tutorial on youtube I figured out: I could do that too and with my own favourite fantasy maps as well. So what I did OUTGAME is: 1. find a picture of the Map of your desire (without provinces)2. Use GIMP to open the map3. FInd all white Color Pixels that are 255/255/255 and change them into 253/253/253 (How you do that? Google if necessary)4. Use the path tool and do Shift+Left Click at all your desired points on the map. (these will be the centers of your provinces (be aware that 1500 is the max for the game)5. Use the Voronoi Path plugin (need to install it) and make a right click on the path window to choose the option Voronoi path6. Choose the option "Preserve the original path"7. Now you have to paths: the original path dots you made and the path net you created with Voronoi path.8. Choose the Path tool and choose the option "Stroke path" to draw the Voronoi path net onto the picture (tada you have your provinces borders ready)9. Choose the pencil tool and chance its brush to "1Pixel". Choose the foreground color 255/255/255 white. 10. Select your original single dots path and select the path tool and the option "Stroke path" and the option "stroke with paint tool" and use the pencil. When it's done then there should be a single white pixes in each province.11. Now the map is ready to use in the map editor. (Takes may be 30 mins to do all that, but you can use any map you like)So year I am now about to finish my big map 1500 Provinces and I do a lot of test in betweens and it is a lot of fun.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Best game of its kind i have played.  Dont let the looks fool you.  Although i agree with others that it could use a bit of polish in the graphics department, i would never never trade game play for eye candy.  Tired of buying all the new AAA titles looking for a challenge and burning up your graphics card in the process?  Get This Game! It will burn up your brain instead as you struggle to choose between so many options... What race to lead, what leader should you play, which units should you build, where, what about magic research, narrow or broad, intense or as needed.  Do I empower my leader or my other minions or hold on to all those crystals for actual combat?  And thats just a tiny bit of what you think your in control of.  Then there's all those other guys scheming against you and totally random events that can help or hinder you in small ways or out right be game changers.  53 hours on record as Im writting this review, and I've won exactly one game, on a small map vs one ai player on easy setting, totally by accident I admit (I had no idea the last move i was making was the winning move.)  I see hundreds more hours of fun and frustration waitting for me.  Trust me on this one, you wont be dissapointed.

Product received for free
												>ATTENTION! GAME PLAYED VIA FAMILY SHARING<Back in the day i thought the Dominions game was just spam spam spam and lose lose lose, young me never learned about the true meat of the game, and thanks to family sharing i was able to do it.One could consider this a God-Game but at the same time not really, in the Dominions series your a Pretender, a person of such power that you are going for the final title of power that matters: Godhood. Unfortunately other people (and... sentient beings to put it nicely) want the same thing, so you gotta earn it through genocide and warfare!Thats pretty much the jist of the game, you pick or create a pretender of various types as well as the age of which the final war takes place (after the stone age to the end of magical fantasty) as well as the faction of man or monster you will rule in the attempt of becoming a God, then you soak the land in the blood of your enemies and armies, for they are little more then tools needed to achieve godhood.Fun game series, dunno where the sequels will go though.
